Advertisers care about four main factors, media presence, nielsen ratings, critical reception, and streamed ratings.
Advetisers care about how many people (and which people) are exposed to their ads. When buying commercial time on TV networks they use Nielsen ratings to determine that and thus set the price for the commercial time. The same goes for streaming ads; they pay based on who watches the ad. The show itself is pretty much just a billboard to them, they don't care about other things related to the show like awards, social media, etc (they do care about their own social media presence but that's a separate matter).
As for No Tomorrow and Frequency, all we the public can do is guess what their streaming numbers were. Now they were likely not very good, but the biggest reason why we can guess that is because we know their live ratings weren't very good and it's reasonable to assume that live and streaming numbers are strongly correlated within shows on the same network.

The CW's situation is not very different from that of the other main broadcast networks (though I will applaud their PR team for convincing people otherwise).
Unlike major networks that puts Hulu and Netflix above their own streaming services and limits what content is on their streaming service, the CW has a platform that is pretty much "free Hulu".
All the networks have their shows on their own service; how much access they give varies by network but is overly pretty similar:
* CW: Last 5 episodes are available to stream without any login * Fox: all episodes of current seasons are available to stream, with only the most recent episode sometimes requiring a cable login to watch (varies by show) * ABC: Last 5 episodes are available to stream, with only the most recent requiring a cable login just for the first week after it originally aired (upon further investigation it looks like for some shows the rest of the current season is available to stream with a cable login) * NBC: Last 5 episodes are available to stream without login, rest of current season available to stream with cable login (though a few shows don't require this) * CBS: Last 5 episodes are available to stream without login, rest of current season available to stream with subscription to All-Access.
(These are for streaming from the networks' websites. Cross-referencing with the apps on my 3rd gen Apple TV yields only a few slight differences which go both ways for NBC, ABC, and FOX, while the CBS app is only for All-Access and the CW app isn't available. I'm guessing the apps will vary slightly across other platforms as well)
As for Hulu, it's owned by NBC, FOX, and ABC (30% each, with WB owning the remaining 10%), so those networks selling streaming rights to Hulu is still somewhat in-house. And CBS has it's own subscription streaming service (All-Access).
Cutting ties with netflix or hulu is something the major networks will not do for the foreseeable future.
The CW recently ditched Hulu but at the same time strengthened its ties to Netflix. Meanwhile 3 of the big 4 have no reason to cut ties with Hulu because they own it.
